title: Rusty, our 1962 11 window bus, resto now in year two…...

posts.content:
Evening all

No wisdom has been forthcoming on the pop out latches but I've got a theory which I'll come to later in this post

As an aside, Dad and I had another trip out on Tuesday. I told him I'd bought another Vespa.

When we got to the place in Luton where we were collecting he got a surprise. I didn't take a photo at the time but did once we got home. There were a few white lies told along the way, but after calling me a few names I think I've been forgiven



A Triumph Tiger Cub T20. He had one as a lad, and has been wanting one to restore for a while now. I've told him he can start on it once the Vespa's done

Anyway…… back to the bus and this bit.



by now the Fertan was nice and dry, so not really knowing the best way to begin, I gave it a good rub down to get any loose bits and dust off and give it a key. Then gave it a light coat of etch primer and got the heater on it. Sorry forgot to photograph

Whilst that was drying I turned my attention to one of the cab doors.



I've tried to fill the holes with weld, but doing the "torch test" from behind keeps revealing more pin holes. I don't think the door is bad enough to warrant buying a new lower skin and frame repair but that's always my fallback position.

I cut out the thinning areas and will replace with some new metal. I've already made a repair patch up for the underside but the problem was always going to be welding to the bit that goes in the seam. I decided to have a little play…. I made up and shaped a bit to the profile of the door




it goes here



tacked into place



and after that I welded it in and shaped it to fit my repair panel, but enough of that, the paint was now dry so good key with some 80 grit ( and I know the pro's are probably pi55ing themselves laughing at my efforts, but I really am making it up as I go ) and then I smeared some Fantastic filler on. This photo shows the extent of the pitting



then the Sheila called me in for early tea as Cornelius has Cubs later which gave the filler a half hour to go off but after tea it was back to the cave and lots of rubbing down, back to bare metal in a lot of areas and then some more etch went on.



I reckon about a half to two thirds of the pitting is now gone, or smoothed out so it's coming on. What do I do now????? Same thing again, or some high build and then some stopper?????? Answers on a post please

Now….. the area right at the bottom of the spare wheel well. This has got to be one of the biggest design faults on the bus. You drop your coffee, or put a wet wheel in there after changing to the spare, and any liquid runs down the back and you can't get it out and then it starts to rust I'm thinking about seam sealing it all up to prevent this. What do you all think? What have you all done?? Perhaps you don't spill your coffee but my kids will spill something down there thats for sure


Now, onto the pop out mounts. I have 6 catches, all in varying states of repair, but I think I could get four working catches from the 6, albeit not in pristine condition, but i can work on that.

My theory is that the back most pair, one each side have the captivated nut plates, then a triangle piece goes on ( the unthreaded, clearanced type) then the catch screws to that with 4mm machine screws.

The others, the two on the cargo doors and the front two on the driver's side, have the triangles (the threaded type) spot welded to the doors or the sides of the bus and there is no adjustment. The catches then go onto these.

I have seen posts about "long spoon" catches. What are these, what's the idea and which pop outs do they fit on?

Sorry for all the questions, but if you think this is bad, wait til I get to the engine

Cheers

Steve

Steve,
Go for the long spoons, I'm searching for some for mine. Missed out on a full set of NOS last year. Kicking myself

Rick

Hi mate,

Personally I would seam seal the bottom of the area you mentioned. When I cut mine out there was all sorts in there and it would be a mare to get to if you did spill anything. At least if its all seam sealed what does end up there will evaporate over time and the seams wont be affected.

As for the pitting how deep is the remainder do you think? High build would probably be your best option but if its deep I would refill first then high build afterwards, but I'm far from good at bodywork so thats a gut instinct rather than professional opinion!!

Long spoon latches have a longer arm so they open further and look pretty in the process, other than that they do the same job. As for the plates I don't have a clue why some adjust and others don't, mine are the same as yours except they have been modded so they all open backwards so I had to buy the spacer plates as on the cargo door and work with what I had! Its a minefield isnt it!!

Looking forward to the engine part! Its great fun compared to bodywork honest!!!

Thanks guys.

I reckon I need to find two more catches then to make up a working set. I'll look out for the longspoon ones. The others are serviceable but I can replace as and when. I need to order the threaded triangle now and one spacer type but I'm not paying £6 postage for just those. There must be something else that I need, apart from a fuel cap. Perhaps AHS do longspoons .....

No news on my engine or gearbox yet, but then I don't need them for a while..

Steve

rusty1962 wrote:


Perhaps AHS do longspoons .....


Steve


Well they're not cheap are they? Think I'm in the wrong game
Just ordered my Safaris, front and rear from Creative
Oooh exciting, shiny or to paint?

wejjy wrote:
Oooh exciting, shiny or to paint?


Shiny. Polished aluminium.

Haven't decided on the side pop outs yet. Need to evaluate the condition of mine but for aesthetics I think I favour painted along the sides. What d'ya reckon?

Steve

rusty1962 wrote:
wejjy wrote:
Oooh exciting, shiny or to paint?


Shiny. Polished aluminium.

Haven't decided on the side pop outs yet. Need to evaluate the condition of mine but for aesthetics I think I favour painted along the sides. What d'ya reckon?

Steve


I went for the bling and have 6 polished shinies down the sides. In my opinion if you have polished front (and rear in your case), polished along the sides is the only way! Sup to you though mate, everyones different, thats what makes the scene so cool!!

wejjy wrote:
rusty1962 wrote:
wejjy wrote:
Oooh exciting, shiny or to paint?


Shiny. Polished aluminium.

Haven't decided on the side pop outs yet. Need to evaluate the condition of mine but for aesthetics I think I favour painted along the sides. What d'ya reckon?

Steve


I went for the bling and have 6 polished shinies down the sides. In my opinion if you have polished front (and rear in your case), polished along the sides is the only way! Sup to you though mate, everyones different, thats what makes the scene so cool!!


Ohhhhhh! I wish you hadn't said that

Sorry, am I too late to join in the window-cutlery discussion?

Long spoons are correct for earlier buses; for our 62s the shorter later catches are correct, although I have spoons because I like them.

There are also medium/short spoons which are sometimes mistakenly attributed as being 'early' long spoons. In fact the deluxe spec was to have five long spoons and one medium spoon. The medium one goes on the front cargo door so that when the cargo door is open on its check strap the open window doesn't foul the cab door when the passenger gets out.

Spoon latches have a rubber stopper on the arm which is meant to rest against the frame when they're open. Some of mine don't (the arm sits slightly too far out of the open window), which may be due to incorrect spacing - I didn't fit them and neither are they original to the bus.

Project's looking ace by the way, lots of work going in and lots of progress being made

clymoj wrote:
Sorry, am I too late to join in the window-cutlery discussion?

There are also medium/short spoons which are sometimes mistakenly attributed as being 'early' long spoons. In fact the deluxe spec was to have five long spoons and one medium spoon. The medium one goes on the front cargo door so that when the cargo door is open on its check strap the open window doesn't foul the cab door when the passenger gets out.

Spoon latches have a rubber stopper on the arm which is meant to rest against the frame when they're open. Some of mine don't (the arm sits slightly too far out of the open window), which may be due to incorrect spacing - I didn't fit them and neither are they original to the bus.

Project's looking ace by the way, lots of work going in and lots of progress being made


Hi Clymoj, thanks for your informative post At the rate I'm going, nothing's ever too late

Rick T has been good enough to offer me two catches that he doesn't need, for which I am very grateful and will profer lots of beer when we eventually meet Incidentally, I've only ever met two people off here and they've both gone quiet of late Coops and Readyboy 61. C'mon fellas, where are you? Hopefully meet you at VF?

Cheers

Steve

Evening all

If one thing can be said for filler work, it's that it's not very photogenic, and it takes ages, but that's two things

Last night , I'd got to here,



better, but not good enough for my spare wheel to sit on

so I got some more filler on, let it dry, sanded back, repeat again. Look Wejjy, I'm ambidextrous



Jon the Builder said he'd give his right arm to be ambidextrous

I think that after the next coat of etch - cos I keep rubbing bits back to metal - it'll be good enough for some high build primer and then I might have a go with some Dolphin Glaze. It's a bit overkill but good practice for when I come to do the bits that will show. I'm going to risk upsetting my painter again by using cellulose, but as I've already done the cab in it, I doubt whether this little bit will make much difference I think I'll have it all Barcoated.



in between times, whilst filler was drying, I haven't been idle

I welded the repair patches into the cab door that I've been playing with





It's come out quite well. I've sorted out all the pin holes but have got a bit of distortion, but only right at the bottom where I've been welding. Some of it should tap out and the rest will be filled now I've had a bit of practice



As result of ordering my Safaris, I now have available one genuine front window glass, in average condition, or perhaps poor to average and one rear small window glass in good condition - I was going to use it before the rear safari idea. What are they worth?

That's all for now til the weekend as it's golf tomorrow and the weather looks good

Cheers

Steve

My advice ....based on learning the skill...45 years ago...and not used since... is have a go at lead loading..
It is THE way to go..I have watched Dave do it and dare I say it sympathised but he has learned by trying and he is ace...
It is enduring and not absorbant...it gives a superb finish,,,
try it around your dog legs.....

SORRY..
